awd_titl_txt: Topology, Singularities and Emulation in a Spinor BEC
awd_abstract_narration:
A frontier of modern physics involves the manipulation and study of atoms cooled and trapped with temperatures near zero degrees Kelvin. Dilute samples of cold atoms have been used to realize high-performance atomic clocks and deBroglie wave gyroscopes as well as to model novel quantum materials. This project is based on the use of such ultracold quantum-atomic vapors to simulate and emulate problems from a range of subfields of physics. The importance of this work includes contributions to the general progress of science and specifically to our understanding of the quantum world. A key impact is expected to be the creation of knowledge useful for the development of quantum technologies and understanding of novel materials. Of equal importance is that the research will be central to the training of the next generation of scientists, many of whom will form the taskforce that is necessary to develop these new technologies.

The project team uses carefully prepared laser pulses to manipulate a quantum degenerate gas of rubidium in such a way that its subsequent behavior models physical phenomena important to problems in other areas such as materials science and nuclear spin resonance (the phenomena at the heart of technologies such as MRI). The project rests on a series of studies related to this goal that build on the group's experience with imprinting spin and orbital angular momentum structures on a spinor Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC).  Specifically the group will investigate the creation, stability and excitations of an array of non-trivial topological excitations (coreless vortices such as Skyrmions, Alice strings, phase states, etc.); to use a recently realized full Bloch BEC to gain access to a topological phase, the Gouy phase; to realize and investigate point-like defects in a spinor BEC such as the cross dis-gyration texture. The proposed work shares a common platform of experimental techniques, many of which are well developed by the group, and a common theoretical framework.

por.por_cntn:
Topology has been at the heart of many of the biggest advances in physics over the last century. Topology has cemented its place as an essential tool that will remain central to developments in physics for decades to come. One of the strengths of topology is its ability to connect phenomena from far-removed fields of physics. This is in particular true of our results.  One of the subfields of topology in mathematics is the theory of knots; indeed knots are some of the earliest topological objects we might encounter as young children learning to tie our shoelaces. Yet knots are mathematically and physically complex objects: in physical systems they signify topological defects or singularities in the structure of a medium. Their complexity means that they have only been successfully realized in quantum fluids and in optics within the last two decades. In quantum fluids, such as a BEC some notable results include the observation of knot solitons and singular vortices in spin-1 condensates, which have been generated by magnetic imprinting or optical stirring techniques. A far richer topology offered by spin-2 manifolds with complex discrete symmetries is still almost entirely unexplored.  In our work we have theoretically proposed and experimentally demonstrated a fundamentally new method of creating quantum knots in spin-1 and spin-2 atomic systems using the quantum mechanical wavefunction of an ultracold spinor Bose gas.  

 

As a result of NSF funding we were also able to initiated new work on the nature of thermodynamics in the context of a quantum system -- the BEC.  Specifically we carried out experiments exploring the fundamental nature of time and the meaning of the so-called Arrow of Time, the observation that in the world, as we experience it, time always moved in one direction as it advances.  We have contributed to answering the question, How?

 

This project has generated many conference papers, the majority of which were presented by graduate and undergraduate students.  In addition, we report eight peer-reviewed publications that offer public access to our work.  These include papers published in some of the most prestigious journals such as those published by the Nature family.  We also reference 13 conference papers reflecting presentations at major US and International meetings describing our work.  Most of these were student presentations

 

A key outcome of our work has been the development of the next generation quantum technology workforce.  Funds have supported work of t four graduate students who have all finished their Ph.D. degrees and are successfully employed.  We have also supported the training and research of five undergraduate students during both the summer and during the usual academic year. Four of these undergraduates are now in graduate school and the remaining student works in a quantum technology start-up.
